citations.narrative:
The housing facilities are not being designed and constructed to contain the animals securely. An indoor housing primary
enclosure was observed to contain a single juvenile Yorkshire Terrier adjacent to an enclosure housing 3 juvenile
Yorkshire Terrier puppies from the same litter. When the facility representative was asked why the single puppy was
being housed alone, they responded that the puppy likely jumped over the divider into the adjacent enclosure. During the
inspection one of the three puppies was observed jumping over the divider into the adjacent enclosure with the single
puppy. Additionally, it was noted that a single enclosure in the sheltered housing section of the facility was housing 8 adult
Yorkshire Terrier dogs where the rest of the enclosures were housing between 2-4 dogs. When inquiring about why this
enclosure is housing more dogs than is being observed in the rest of the facility, the representative stated the dogs have
jumped into this enclosure from adjacent enclosures.
The primary enclosures not effectively containing the animals could lead to the animals being injured while jumping over
dividers, compatibility issues between dogs, or an animal escaping the facility. Housing facilities for dogs must be
designed and constructed so they are structurally sound. They must be kept in good repair, and they must protect the
animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and restrict other animals from entering.
Correct by 23 October 2025

The facility is not following the Program of Veterinary Care for vaccinations. The Program of Veterinary Care currently
prescribes dogs will be vaccinated for Distemper, Parvo, Hepatitis, and Leptospirosis annually. Additionally, the Program
of Veterinary Care prescribes a rabies vaccine will be given at 16 weeks of age, at 1 year after the initial vaccine and then
every 1 or 3 years depending on the labeled vaccine.
1 adult female dog (#8395) is not currently up to date on the DAPP/Lepto (7-way) or rabies vaccine. The last recorded 7-
way vaccine was administered on 2 March 2024. The last recorded rabies vaccine which was labeled as a 1-year vaccine
was administered on 2 March 2024.
Failure to follow the preventative care schedule for vaccinations in the Program of Veterinary Care does not ensure the
dogs are receiving appropriate protection against contagious and deadly diseases such as distemper, parvo,
leptospirosis, and rabies which can lead to illness and discomfort to the dogs. The facility must follow the vaccination
schedule approved by the attending veterinarian in the Program of Veterinary Care to protect the dogs from deadly or
contagious diseases.
Correct by 9 October 2025

An adult female Yorkshire Terrier # 900215000188743 has excessively long toenails. The nails on all four feet are long
and curl to the side when standing on a flat surface. The facility representative states they typically groom and trim the
nails of all dogs every 2 months.
The Program of Veterinary Care states that nails will be trimmed to allow dogs to walk in a normal manner, excessively
long toenails will not be permitted, and the trimming frequency will vary between kennels. Excessively long toenails can
result in pain and discomfort to the dogs and prevent the animal from standing or walking normally. Long toenails are also
more likely to break and result in injury to the animal. The licensee must follow their preventative care and treatment plans
to ensure healthy and un-matted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth and
ensure it is effective at maintaining healthy husbandry for the dog.
Correct by 2 October 2025

The facility was unable to provide medical records for two juvenile Cavapoo puppies being treated for an illness. While
reviewing cage cards during the inspection it was observed puppy 25-53 and 25-56 died on 10 August 2025 and 31 July
2025 respectively. When inquiring about the deaths of the puppies the facility representative stated the puppies had
developed diarrhea which were treated per the Program of Veterinary Care with Albon (5 days of treatment) and
Toltrazuril (3 days of treatment). When the APHIS official requested to see the medical records for these dogs the facility
representative stated he did not document the treatment of the puppies on a medical record.
Failure to document on a medical record when a problem is identified with the date and description of the problem along
with the plan for treatment and the names of all treatments and the dates of administration may interfere with the ability of
APHIS officials to determine if the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care.
The facility must ensure that medical records for dogs are available for APHIS inspection and if a problem is identified
(such as a disease, injury, or illness, the date and a description of the problem, examination findings, test results, plan for
treatment and care, and the treatment procedures performed, when appropriate, are documented on a medical record
and maintained. Furthermore, the names of all vaccines and treatments administered, and the dates of administration are
recorded and maintained.
Correct by 9 October 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Louis Divincenti n

narrative:
3.1(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
The housing facilities are not being designed and constructed to contain the animals securely. An indoor housing primary 
enclosure was observed to contain a single juvenile Yorkshire Terrier adjacent to an enclosure housing 3 juvenile

enclosure is housing more dogs than is being observed in the rest of the facility, the representative stated the dogs have 
jumped into this enclosure from adjacent enclosures.

designed and constructed so they are structurally sound. They must be kept in good repair, and they must protect the 
animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and restrict other animals from entering.

3.13(a)(3)

3.13(a)(4)
